# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is the Julia code that fulfills your requirements:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df = copy(df)  # create a copy of the dataframe so we don't modify the original
    filter!(r -> (r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro")), df)  # Filter rows with manufacturer "audi" and model as "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df[:audi_a4_type] = true  # Create a new column 'audi_a4_type' that equals true across all the filtered rows
    return df
end
```
Please note that this code requires `DataFrames` and `CategoricalArrays` packages. You can install these by running `using Pkg; Pkg.add("DataFrames"); Pkg.add("CategoricalArrays")` in your Julia environment.
You call the function as follows: 
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
